STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
April 19, 2022
Fred Baker II
Jackson County Youth Center
930 Fleming Avenue
Jackson, MI 49202
RE: License #: CO380201204
Dear Mr. Baker:
This letter is a follow-up to the Department’s findings regarding the interim inspection
conducted at your facility on 04/18/2022. The purpose of this inspection was to determine
compliance with applicable licensing statutes and administrative rules for Court Operated
Residential Care Facility. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and/or rule.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective actin plan, a regular certificate of inspection
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary
action will result.
Please review the enclosed document for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS/Division of Child Welfare Licensing
248-860-4532
LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

I. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The violations that were found are:
R 400.10177 Resident restraint.
(7) Each use of material or mechanical restraint equipment shall
be documented in a written record and shall include all of the
following information:
(a) The name of the resident.
(b) The name of the administrator or designee who
authorized the use of the equipment, and the time of the
authorization.
(c) The time the restraint equipment was applied.
(d) The name of the staff member who was responsible for
the application.
(e) A description of the specific behavior that necessitated
its use.
(f) The name of the staff person(s) who was continuously
with the resident.
(g) The date and time of removal of the equipment and the
name of the person removing the equipment.
A conversation with the chief administrator revealed the facility does not document
all of the items listed in (a) – (g) when mechanical restraints are applied, which
includes for the purpose of transporting youth.
R 400.10317 Updated service plan.
(1) An updated service plan shall be completed and
recorded by the social worker for each facility resident at
least once every 3 months after completing the initial
service plan.
One of one updated service plan reviewed was completed 30 days late. A
conversation with the social worker revealed that she relies on the facility’s
software system (Bitstream) to alert her when service plans are due and the
system does not always calculate accurate due dates.
2

II. CONSULTATION
In the course of reviewing meal menus and interviewing staff, it was discovered
the facility has been without and/or short on cooks, which has led to floor staff
cooking meals and ordering out. When meals divert from those on the planned
menu, it is best practice to “write in” on the menu the actual foods that were
served during that particular meal.
Dental services for the youth are frequently obtained by a mobile organization
called Smiles on Wheels. The organization provides documentation of the
service provided, but it does not include the provider’s signature. To verify that
an actual dental exam occurred, it is best practice that the service provider signs
the document.
Release plans are computer-generated. The drop-down screen for “title of
person to whom youth was released” is limited and does not give DHHS worker
or transporter as options. In these instances, the writer chooses “other” which
does not identify that person’s title or role. I advised that the actual “title” of the
person is either manually written in on the form or that the software is
reprogrammed to include all the possible titles of persons to whom youths may
be released.
III. EVALUATION OF INTERIM PERIOD
The facility has a total capacity of 50 beds, 26 treatment and 24 short-term. On
the date of this inspection, the census was 4 in treatment and 12 in short-term for
a total of 16 youth.
I toured the facility and observed youth bedrooms, common areas, the
medication room, control rooms, clothing storage room, camera monitors, room
speaker system, classrooms, seclusion rooms and staff offices. I reviewed room
monitoring sheets, seclusion logs, updated policies, meal menus, employee files
(paper) and open and closed youth files (electronic), and spoke with
administrative, supervisory, and social work staff.
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care and no corrective
action plans required for special investigations during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan was submitted for the Renewal Inspection report dated
3/16/21 in which the following rule violations were cited:
R 400.10209 (1) Resident report
R 400.10211 (1) (c) Resident release report
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the inspection findings, the facility is not in compliance with all
applicable rules and statutes. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action
plan, it is recommended the facility continue their current licensing status.
April 19, 2022
Deborah Will Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 19, 2022
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
